<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Two 1D coordination polymers, [Cu(mal)(Hdpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Cu(mal)(tpy)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), are formed by using maleate ligands bridges and chelate aromatic ligands. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each pair of 1D chains recognize each other through powerful hydrogen bond and aromatic π–π stacking interactions to generate a zipperlike double chains. In contrast, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is directly constructed into 2D zipperlike layers by the unprecedented aromatic π–π stacking interactions that same orientated aromatic chelate ligands are simultaneously attached to both sides of the chain and the significant C–H⋯O hydrogen bonds. More interesting, these layers are constructed through hydrogen bonds to result in a 3D supramolecular network with 1D open channels, in which exists an unprecedented one-dimensional water chain.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two 1D coordination polymers, [Cu(mal)(Hdpa)] n  (1) and {[Cu(mal)(tpy)]⋅4 H2O} n  (2), are formed by using maleate ligands bridges and chelate aromatic ligands. In 1, each pair of 1D chains recognize each other through powerful hydrogen bond and aromatic π-π stacking interactions to generate a zipperlike double chains. In contrast, complex 2 is directly constructed into 2D zipperlike layers by the unprecedented aromatic π-π stacking interactions that same orientated aromatic chelate ligands are simultaneously attached to both sides of the chain and the significant C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds. More interesting, these layers are constructed through hydrogen bonds to result in a 3D supramolecular network with 1D open channels, in which exists an unprecedented one-dimensional water chain.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Two 1D coordination polymers, [Cu(mal)(Hdpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Cu(mal)(tpy)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (mal<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>maleate, Hdpa<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, 2′-dipyridylamine and tpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine), have been synthesized and their crystal structures, IR spectra, thermal analyses, magnetic properties were determined. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the maleate ligands link adjacent metal centers to form 1D coordination polymeric chains. Furthermore, the carboxylate oxygen atoms and the aromatic chelate ligands provide potential supramolecular recognition sites for noncovalent interactions to form higher dimensionality. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each pair of 1D chains recognize each other through strong hydrogen bond formed by active amine (–NH–) hydrogen and aromatic π–π stacking interactions to generate a zipperlike double-stranded chain. In contrast, when the substitutions of tpy for dpa further enhance the π–π aromatic stacking interactions, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is directly constructed into 2D zipperlike layers by the unprecedented aromatic π–π stacking interactions that same orientated aromatic chelate ligands are simultaneously attached to both sides of the chain and the significant C–H⋯O hydrogen bonds. These layers are constructed through hydrogen bonds and result in a 3D supramolecular network with 1D open channels, in which exists an unprecedented one-dimensional water chain. Both were magnetically characterized, showing weak ferromagnetic behavior.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two 1D coordination polymers, [Cu(mal)(Hdpa)] n  (1) and {[Cu(mal)(tpy)]⋅4H2O} n  (2) (mal=maleate, Hdpa=2, 2'-dipyridylamine and tpy=2,2':6',2"-terpyridine), have been synthesized and their crystal structures, IR spectra, thermal analyses, magnetic properties were determined. In 1 and 2, the maleate ligands link adjacent metal centers to form 1D coordination polymeric chains. Furthermore, the carboxylate oxygen atoms and the aromatic chelate ligands provide potential supramolecular recognition sites for noncovalent interactions to form higher dimensionality. In 1, each pair of 1D chains recognize each other through strong hydrogen bond formed by active amine (-NH-) hydrogen and aromatic π-π stacking interactions to generate a zipperlike double-stranded chain. In contrast, when the substitutions of tpy for dpa further enhance the π-π aromatic stacking interactions, complex 2 is directly constructed into 2D zipperlike layers by the unprecedented aromatic π-π stacking interactions that same orientated aromatic chelate ligands are simultaneously attached to both sides of the chain and the significant C-H⋯O hydrogen bonds. These layers are constructed through hydrogen bonds and result in a 3D supramolecular network with 1D open channels, in which exists an unprecedented one-dimensional water chain. Both were magnetically characterized, showing weak ferromagnetic behavior.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Organic–inorganic hybrid materials have been studied for their intriguing topologies and potential applications in gas storage, catalysis, separations, and molecular recognition . Only very recently have attempts been made to combine both coordination bonds and weaker non-covalent forces such as hydrogen bonding and π–π contacts to crystal engineer organic–inorganic materials . In this regard, the dicarboxylic acids are good candidate as bridging ligands for designing new organic–inorganic hybrid materials as it may participate in both types of interaction as well as their diverse coordination modes. Furthermore, the dicarboxylic acids, as a superexchange pathways between the metal ions [Cu(II), Mn(II), Ni(II), etc.], have received considerable attention in the field of molecular magnetism . Therefore, the dicarboxylic acids such as oxalate, malonate, terephthalate  and, to a less degree, maleate  are used to construct interesting molecular topologies and crystal packing motif. On the other hand, in spite of polycyclic aromatic ligands such as 2,2′-bipyridyl and 1,10-phenanthroline frequently being used in combination with dicarboxylates and leading to novel architectures where they facilitate supramolecular self-assembly through aromatic–aromatic (π–π and CH–π) interactions , studies on 2,2′-dipyridylamine (Hdpa) or 2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine (tpy) with dicarboxylates are less reported . Considering the mal and dpa/tpy may provide potential supramolecular recognition sites for noncovalent interactions to form higher dimensionality along with interesting magnetic properties of dicarboxylates, our work focused on Cu(mal) and Hdpa/tpy.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Organic-inorganic hybrid materials have been studied for their intriguing topologies and potential applications in gas storage, catalysis, separations, and molecular recognition . Only very recently have attempts been made to combine both coordination bonds and weaker non-covalent forces such as hydrogen bonding and π-π contacts to crystal engineer organic-inorganic materials . In this regard, the dicarboxylic acids are good candidate as bridging ligands for designing new organic-inorganic hybrid materials as it may participate in both types of interaction as well as their diverse coordination modes. Furthermore, the dicarboxylic acids, as a superexchange pathways between the metal ions [Cu(II), Mn(II), Ni(II), etc.], have received considerable attention in the field of molecular magnetism . Therefore, the dicarboxylic acids such as oxalate, malonate, terephthalate  and, to a less degree, maleate  are used to construct interesting molecular topologies and crystal packing motif. On the other hand, in spite of polycyclic aromatic ligands such as 2,2'-bipyridyl and 1,10-phenanthroline frequently being used in combination with dicarboxylates and leading to novel architectures where they facilitate supramolecular self-assembly through aromatic-aromatic (π-π and CH-π) interactions , studies on 2,2'-dipyridylamine (Hdpa) or 2,2':6',2"-terpyridine (tpy) with dicarboxylates are less reported . Considering the mal and dpa/tpy may provide potential supramolecular recognition sites for noncovalent interactions to form higher dimensionality along with interesting magnetic properties of dicarboxylates, our work focused on Cu(mal) and Hdpa/tpy.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Herein, we will report the synthesis, structure characterization and magnetic characterization of two maleate bridged Cu(II) complexes [Cu(mal)(Hdpa)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and {[Cu(mal)(tpy)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The two novel coordination polymers are based on topologically identical chains where the copper centers chelated by amine ligands are linked through mal bridges. Significantly, the chains may also be interacted under direction of supramolecular recognition and attraction through π–π aromatic stacking interactions and hydrogen-bonding interactions into molecular zipperlike double-stranded chains or 3D supramolecular network with 1D open channels. The most remarkable feature in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is that there exists hydrogen-bonding one-dimensional water chain in the open channels.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Herein, we will report the synthesis, structure characterization and magnetic characterization of two maleate bridged Cu(II) complexes [Cu(mal)(Hdpa)] n  1 and {[Cu(mal)(tpy)]⋅4H2O} n  2. The two novel coordination polymers are based on topologically identical chains where the copper centers chelated by amine ligands are linked through mal bridges. Significantly, the chains may also be interacted under direction of supramolecular recognition and attraction through π-π aromatic stacking interactions and hydrogen-bonding interactions into molecular zipperlike double-stranded chains or 3D supramolecular network with 1D open channels. The most remarkable feature in 2 is that there exists hydrogen-bonding one-dimensional water chain in the open channels.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All chemicals were purchased commercially and used as received. Elemental analyses were determined with a Perkin–Elmer model 240C automatic analytical instrument. IR spectra (4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) were recorded on KBr pellets with a Nicolet 170SX FT-IR spectrometer. Differential thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C microanalyzer under flowing air with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min. Variable-temperature (2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) magnetic susceptibility measurement was carried out on a Maglab System 2000 susceptometer (made in Oxford, UK). The magnetometer was operated at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>T magnetic field. The diamagnetic correction was evaluated from Pascal’s constants.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

All chemicals were purchased commercially and used as received. Elemental analyses were determined with a Perkin-Elmer model 240C automatic analytical instrument. IR spectra (4000-400cm-1) were recorded on KBr pellets with a Nicolet 170SX FT-IR spectrometer. Differential thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) were performed on a Netzsch STA 449C microanalyzer under flowing air with a heating rate of 10°C/min. Variable-temperature (2-300K) magnetic susceptibility measurement was carried out on a Maglab System 2000 susceptometer (made in Oxford, UK). The magnetometer was operated at 1T magnetic field. The diamagnetic correction was evaluated from Pascal's constants.

elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of the complexes

[Cu(mal)(Hdpa)] n  (1)

A suspension of maleate Cu(II) salt (17.8mg, 1mmol) and Hdpa (19.2mg, 1mmol) in methanol solution (10mL) were stirred at room temperature until all the starting materials had dissolved and were replaced with a green powdery precipitate. The mixture was filtered, and a green, clear solution was obtained; dark green crystals of 1 were formed upon standing of the filtrate at room temperature 2 days (9.8mg 28.2%). Anal. Calc. for C14H11CuN3O4 (348.80): C, 48.17; H, 3.15; N, 12.04. Found: C, 48.32; H, 3.01; N, 12.20%.

{[Cu(mal)(tpy)]⋅4H2O}n (2)

Complex 2 was prepared similar to 1. A suspension of maleate Cu(II) salt (17.8mg, 1mmol) and tpy (23.8mg, 1mmol) in methanol solution (15mL) were stirred at room temperature until all the starting materials had dissolved and formed a dark green, clear solution that was immediately filtered; dark green crystals of 2 were formed upon standing of the filtrate at room temperature 3 days (35.3mg 73.1%). elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Data collection (single crystal with dimensions of 0.15×0.15×0.04mm3 for 1 and 0.536×0.497×0.332mm3 for 2) was performed at 295(2)K for 1 and 293(2)K for 2 on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer equipped with Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.071073nm). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with shelxtl-pc v 5.03 software package . The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and the hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were placed geometrically. A summary of the crystallographic data for 1 and 2 is presented in  .

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Description of crystal structure

Both complexes are constructed by 1D chains where distorted square-pyramidal Cu(II) centers are linked by mal bridges. However, the structures significantly differ in the coordination environment, coordination modes of the mal ligands and chain packing. Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 and 2 are listed in   , respectively.

<ce:section-title>Structures of individual chains in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the copper atoms are coordinated to exhibit a CuN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> distorted square-pyramidal environment, the <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic> value being 0.230 (square-pyramidal and trigonal-pyramidal surroundings corresponding to <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0 and <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1, respectively.) . The equatorial plane around Cu1 is build by two N atoms of one Hdpa ligand and two O atoms of two different mal ligands (the average value of Cu–N and mean Cu–O bonds being 1.966(5) and 1.979(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The apical position is occupied by a maleate–oxygen atom (2.366(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Cu1–O1). Each pair of adjacent Cu atoms is bridged by a mal ligand to form a 1D polymeric chain extending along [0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1] direction with an adjacent Cu⋯Cu distance of 7.1753(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. It can be noted that two carboxylate groups of the mal ligand have two coordination modes. In the first mode, the carboxylate group monatomically coordinates one Cu atom in the <ce:italic>syn</ce:italic> fashion (through O3 toward Cu1) and the other chelating one Cu atom (through O1, O2 toward Cu1). The dpa ligands are extended uniquely at one side of the chain in a parallel fashion ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structures of individual chains in 1 and 2 

In the complex 1, the copper atoms are coordinated to exhibit a CuN2O3 distorted square-pyramidal environment, the τ value being 0.230 (square-pyramidal and trigonal-pyramidal surroundings corresponding to τ =0 and τ =1, respectively.) . The equatorial plane around Cu1 is build by two N atoms of one Hdpa ligand and two O atoms of two different mal ligands (the average value of Cu-N and mean Cu-O bonds being 1.966(5) and 1.979(4)Å, respectively) ( ). The apical position is occupied by a maleate-oxygen atom (2.366(4)Å for Cu1-O1). Each pair of adjacent Cu atoms is bridged by a mal ligand to form a 1D polymeric chain extending along [001] direction with an adjacent Cu⋯Cu distance of 7.1753(2)Å. It can be noted that two carboxylate groups of the mal ligand have two coordination modes. In the first mode, the carboxylate group monatomically coordinates one Cu atom in the syn fashion (through O3 toward Cu1) and the other chelating one Cu atom (through O1, O2 toward Cu1). The dpa ligands are extended uniquely at one side of the chain in a parallel fashion ().

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">When tpy, a chelate aromatic ligand of a larger size, was used instead of dpa, analogous neutral 1D chains are formed in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. As illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>, the copper atoms in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are five-coordinated CuN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and have distorted square-pyramidal environment, the <ce:italic>τ</ce:italic> value being 0.234. The basal sites around Cu atoms are occupied by three tpy-nitrogen atoms (1.939(2), 2.040(2), 2.064(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Cu1–N(1, 2, 3), respectively) and one carboxylate–oxygen atom (1.9226(17)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Cu1–O1) from a maleate ligand. The apical position is occupied by a maleate–oxygen atom, and the value of the bond length (2.1800(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for Cu1–O3A) is significantly longer than the equatorial one. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the environment of copper atoms is modified by incorporation of a tpy instead of dpa, resulting in change of a coordination mode of one carboxylate group from chelating to monodentate. Therefore, the maleate dianion behave as 1,4-bidentate bridging ligands, each carboxylate group as a monodentate ligand to bind a metal ion, to give an infinite line chain with the adjacent Cu⋯Cu distance of 7.7302(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The tpy ligands are extended uniquely at one side of this chain in a slanted fashion ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When tpy, a chelate aromatic ligand of a larger size, was used instead of dpa, analogous neutral 1D chains are formed in 2. As illustrated in  , the copper atoms in 2 are five-coordinated CuN3O2 and have distorted square-pyramidal environment, the τ value being 0.234. The basal sites around Cu atoms are occupied by three tpy-nitrogen atoms (1.939(2), 2.040(2), 2.064(2)Å for Cu1-N(1, 2, 3), respectively) and one carboxylate-oxygen atom (1.9226(17)Å for Cu1-O1) from a maleate ligand. The apical position is occupied by a maleate-oxygen atom, and the value of the bond length (2.1800(2)Å for Cu1-O3A) is significantly longer than the equatorial one. In 2, the environment of copper atoms is modified by incorporation of a tpy instead of dpa, resulting in change of a coordination mode of one carboxylate group from chelating to monodentate. Therefore, the maleate dianion behave as 1,4-bidentate bridging ligands, each carboxylate group as a monodentate ligand to bind a metal ion, to give an infinite line chain with the adjacent Cu⋯Cu distance of 7.7302(1)Å. The tpy ligands are extended uniquely at one side of this chain in a slanted fashion ().

<ce:para view="all">To the best of our knowledge, the maleate anions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> provide the first example of maleate to serve as a tridentate bridging ligand, one terminal carboxylate bridging one Cu atom and the other chelating the second Cu atom (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>(a)). From others work, we are aware that the maleate anions can function as other five bridging modes: mono-bidentate ligands to chelate one metal atom as in [Cu(pz*)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(mal)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O ((b)) ; bis-monodentate ligands linking two metal atoms as in complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> ((c)); tridentate ligands with one carboxylate O atom of one end bidentately bridging two metal atoms and the other end monodentately coordinating one metal atom as in [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(mal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2MeOH ((d)) ; tetradentate ligands with two carboxylate O atom of two end chelately coordinating one metal atom and the other two carboxylate O atom bidentately bridging two metal atoms as in [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(mal)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(MeOH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ((e)) ; tetradentate ligands with one carboxylate O atom of one end bidentately bridging two metal atoms and the other end bidentately bridging two metal atoms as in {[Mn(mal)(4,4′-bipy)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> }<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> ((f)) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To the best of our knowledge, the maleate anions in 1 provide the first example of maleate to serve as a tridentate bridging ligand, one terminal carboxylate bridging one Cu atom and the other chelating the second Cu atom ( (a)). From others work, we are aware that the maleate anions can function as other five bridging modes: mono-bidentate ligands to chelate one metal atom as in [Cu(pz*)2(mal)]⋅1.5H2O ((b)) ; bis-monodentate ligands linking two metal atoms as in complex 2 ((c)); tridentate ligands with one carboxylate O atom of one end bidentately bridging two metal atoms and the other end monodentately coordinating one metal atom as in [Cu2(mal)2(phen)2]⋅4H2O⋅2MeOH ((d)) ; tetradentate ligands with two carboxylate O atom of two end chelately coordinating one metal atom and the other two carboxylate O atom bidentately bridging two metal atoms as in [Mn4(mal)2(bipy)8](ClO4)4 ⋅(H2O)2(MeOH)2 ((e)) ; tetradentate ligands with one carboxylate O atom of one end bidentately bridging two metal atoms and the other end bidentately bridging two metal atoms as in {[Mn(mal)(4,4'-bipy)]⋅0.5(H2O)2 } n  ((f)) .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Chain packing and noncovalent interactions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The structures of individual chains in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are similar but different in amine ligand and coordination mode of mal. The chain packing in the structures, however, is significantly different. In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, each pair of chains recognizes each other through the offset aromatic π–π stacking interactions of the dpa ligands to generate a zipperlike double-stranded chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). The perpendicular distances between the paired dpa ring are alternatively 3.3819 and 3.5179<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, while the centroids distances between the py planes (C<ce:inf loc="post">g</ce:inf>(py)⋯C<ce:inf loc="post">g</ce:inf>(py)) are alternatively 3.7000 and 3.8782<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Such zipperlike chain structures are notably common biochemically, but so far, few examples of zipperlike coordination polymer compounds have been reported . It is noteworthy that the zipperlike double chains reported mostly generate allowing for aromatic π–π stacking interactions. But in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, strong N–H⋯O hydrogen bonds involving the adjacent uncoordinated dpa active amine (–NH–) and uncoordinated mal oxygen atoms (O4) (the distance of N–H⋯O is 2.7950(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the angle is 174.31°) render additional attractions between the pair of strands. To our knowledge, such double chains with strong N–H⋯O hydrogen bonds have not been reported.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Chain packing and noncovalent interactions in 1 and 2 

The structures of individual chains in complex 1 and 2 are similar but different in amine ligand and coordination mode of mal. The chain packing in the structures, however, is significantly different. In complex 1, each pair of chains recognizes each other through the offset aromatic π-π stacking interactions of the dpa ligands to generate a zipperlike double-stranded chain ( ). The perpendicular distances between the paired dpa ring are alternatively 3.3819 and 3.5179Å, while the centroids distances between the py planes (Cg(py)⋯Cg(py)) are alternatively 3.7000 and 3.8782Å. Such zipperlike chain structures are notably common biochemically, but so far, few examples of zipperlike coordination polymer compounds have been reported . It is noteworthy that the zipperlike double chains reported mostly generate allowing for aromatic π-π stacking interactions. But in 1, strong N-H⋯O hydrogen bonds involving the adjacent uncoordinated dpa active amine (-NH-) and uncoordinated mal oxygen atoms (O4) (the distance of N-H⋯O is 2.7950(2)Å and the angle is 174.31°) render additional attractions between the pair of strands. To our knowledge, such double chains with strong N-H⋯O hydrogen bonds have not been reported.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In addition, each double chain is surrounded by six other double chains and the adjacent double chains are connected to produce a 3D network via weak C–H⋯O hydrogen bonding interactions between the oxygen atom of maleate group and the carbon atom belonging to the adjacent double chain (the distances range from 3.2052(3)–3.5333(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>), as well as van der Waals forces.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In addition, each double chain is surrounded by six other double chains and the adjacent double chains are connected to produce a 3D network via weak C-H⋯O hydrogen bonding interactions between the oxygen atom of maleate group and the carbon atom belonging to the adjacent double chain (the distances range from 3.2052(3)-3.5333(5)Å) ( ), as well as van der Waals forces.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In contrast to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the adjacent chains in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are rearranged in zipperlike layers with the same directions of the chain axes. Within the crystal structure, two pyridine rings of tpy (comprising atoms N1 and C1–C5 is designated as ring 1 with centroid C<ce:inf loc="post">g1</ce:inf> and N3 and C11–C15 as ring 2 with centroid C<ce:inf loc="post">g2</ce:inf>) involved in the intermolecular π–π stacking interactions. Unlike dpa in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the two pyridine rings of tpy ligands respectively allow pairing of two symmetry-related pyridine rings of the adjacent single-stranded chains to generate a 2D zipperlike layers with the aromatic π–π stacking interactions (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). The perpendicular distances from C<ce:inf loc="post">g1</ce:inf> to the plane of symmetry-related ring of the adjacent chain, and from C<ce:inf loc="post">g2</ce:inf> to the plane of symmetry-related ring of the adjacent chain are 3.3371, 3.5078Å and 3.3496, 3.6331<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively, and the distances between the ring centroids (C<ce:inf loc="post">g1</ce:inf> and C<ce:inf loc="post">g2</ce:inf>) are 3.627, 5.300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 3.747, 4.224<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The dihedral angle from ring 1 to ring 2 is 20.9°. Additionally, the uncoordinated O2 and O4 acceptors of maleate ligand are engaged in significant hydrogen-bonding interactions with carbon atoms of tpy with O⋯C distances from 3.1240(2) to 3.4153(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which render additional attractions between the adjacent strands. To the best of our knowledge, such zipperlike intercalations presents the first example of that the same orientated aromatic chelate ligands are simultaneously attached to both sides of the chain through aromatic π–π stacking interactions to generate a 2D zipperlike layers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In contrast to 1, the adjacent chains in 2 are rearranged in zipperlike layers with the same directions of the chain axes. Within the crystal structure, two pyridine rings of tpy (comprising atoms N1 and C1-C5 is designated as ring 1 with centroid Cg1 and N3 and C11-C15 as ring 2 with centroid Cg2) involved in the intermolecular π-π stacking interactions. Unlike dpa in 1, the two pyridine rings of tpy ligands respectively allow pairing of two symmetry-related pyridine rings of the adjacent single-stranded chains to generate a 2D zipperlike layers with the aromatic π-π stacking interactions ( ). The perpendicular distances from Cg1 to the plane of symmetry-related ring of the adjacent chain, and from Cg2 to the plane of symmetry-related ring of the adjacent chain are 3.3371, 3.5078Å and 3.3496, 3.6331Å, respectively, and the distances between the ring centroids (Cg1 and Cg2) are 3.627, 5.300Å and 3.747, 4.224Å, respectively. The dihedral angle from ring 1 to ring 2 is 20.9°. Additionally, the uncoordinated O2 and O4 acceptors of maleate ligand are engaged in significant hydrogen-bonding interactions with carbon atoms of tpy with O⋯C distances from 3.1240(2) to 3.4153(2)Å, which render additional attractions between the adjacent strands. To the best of our knowledge, such zipperlike intercalations presents the first example of that the same orientated aromatic chelate ligands are simultaneously attached to both sides of the chain through aromatic π-π stacking interactions to generate a 2D zipperlike layers.

<ce:para view="all">The packing of the complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>. Each lay is interconnected through hydrogen bonds between maleate oxygen atoms and guest water molecules O6w to result in a 3D supramolecular network with 1D channel. Perpendicular to the layers, channels are observed and the void size is about 12.924<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8.329<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å ((a)). An interesting feature is that an infinite chain of hydrogen-bonded water molecules passes through the channel in an unprecedented fashion ((b)). Unexpectedly, the infinite water chain is produced by alternate repetition of cyclic tetramer with one dangling water molecule and chair cyclic hexamer ((b)) with hydrogen-bonding (2.8839(5), 2.8806(5), 3.0230(2), 2.7831(3), 2.7475(5) and 2.7832(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for O7w⋯O5w, O5w⋯O8w O7wA⋯O8w, O5w⋯O8wB, O6w⋯O8w and O8w⋯O5wB, respectively) ((b)).</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In the past decades, a variety of 1D polymeric water has been found in a number of crystal hosts, such as 1D segregated water chain , crankshaft chain , string-of-pearls motif . The 1D water chain structures constituting a potentially important form of water is poorly understood . Many fundamental biological processes appear to depend on the unique properties of water chains . However, the knowledge of structural constraints required in the stabilization of water chains and the influence of the chain structure on the host remains incomplete . The 1D water chains in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> appear to be stabilized by 3D supramolecular network through the hydrogen bond with maleate oxygen atoms and the water molecules (2.7908(5), 2.8680(2) and 2.8324(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for O1⋯O6w, O4⋯O6w and O7w⋯O3, respectively). This information of the 1D water chain is helpful in improving our understanding of the structures and characteristics of liquid water and ice, as well as in biological and chemical processes. Meanwhile, the degree of structuring of the water cluster that can be imposed by its environment, and vice versa, can be of importance in the design of new metal–organic framework (MOF) structures .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the past decades, a variety of 1D polymeric water has been found in a number of crystal hosts, such as 1D segregated water chain , crankshaft chain , string-of-pearls motif . The 1D water chain structures constituting a potentially important form of water is poorly understood . Many fundamental biological processes appear to depend on the unique properties of water chains . However, the knowledge of structural constraints required in the stabilization of water chains and the influence of the chain structure on the host remains incomplete . The 1D water chains in 2 appear to be stabilized by 3D supramolecular network through the hydrogen bond with maleate oxygen atoms and the water molecules (2.7908(5), 2.8680(2) and 2.8324(2)Å for O1⋯O6w, O4⋯O6w and O7w⋯O3, respectively). This information of the 1D water chain is helpful in improving our understanding of the structures and characteristics of liquid water and ice, as well as in biological and chemical processes. Meanwhile, the degree of structuring of the water cluster that can be imposed by its environment, and vice versa, can be of importance in the design of new metal-organic framework (MOF) structures .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Vibrational spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains prominent <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf> stretching bands around 1658, 1562 and 1488, 1433<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. The Δ<ce:italic>v</ce:italic> values (170 and 129<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) are close to the value expected for a unidentate coordination mode and a chelating coordination mode of the carboxylate moiety, respectively . Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the strong bands corresponding to <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>v</ce:italic>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf> at 1592 and 1410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. The Δ<ce:italic>v</ce:italic> value is 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, which is as expected for a unidentate coordination mode of the carboxylate moiety , suggesting that the carboxylate functions may be coordinated to the copper centers in a similar mode.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Vibrational spectra

The IR spectrum of 1 contains prominent v(COO)as and v(COO)s stretching bands around 1658, 1562 and 1488, 1433cm-1, respectively. The Δv values (170 and 129cm-1) are close to the value expected for a unidentate coordination mode and a chelating coordination mode of the carboxylate moiety, respectively . Complex 2 shows the strong bands corresponding to v(COO)as and v(COO)s at 1592 and 1410cm-1, respectively. The Δv value is 180cm-1, which is as expected for a unidentate coordination mode of the carboxylate moiety , suggesting that the carboxylate functions may be coordinated to the copper centers in a similar mode.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Thermal analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">To study the thermal stability of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, thermogravimetric analyses and differential scanning calorimetry (TGA and DSC) were performed. The TGA results of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> show that no obvious decomposition was observed until about 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and prove no water molecules in polymers. But the TG curves of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show the first stage of weight loss from 80 to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is mainly due to the release of four water molecules per formula unit. The observed weight loss (14.85% <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) is close to the calculated one (14.91% <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), indicating that the weight loss of water molecules is consistent with the compounds described. Between 200 and 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C the weight loss is noticeable for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, accompanying amassing of heat, corresponding to the decomposition and oxidation of mal and aromatic chelate ligands. The final product of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is all CuO. The experimental residual percentage weights (23.08% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and 16.66% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) at the end of the decomposition of the polymers are consistent with the calculated values of 22.94% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 16.57% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analyses

To study the thermal stability of complexes 1 and 2, thermogravimetric analyses and differential scanning calorimetry (TGA and DSC) were performed. The TGA results of 1 show that no obvious decomposition was observed until about 200°C and prove no water molecules in polymers. But the TG curves of 2 show the first stage of weight loss from 80 to 120°C is mainly due to the release of four water molecules per formula unit. The observed weight loss (14.85% 2) is close to the calculated one (14.91% 2), indicating that the weight loss of water molecules is consistent with the compounds described. Between 200 and 450°C the weight loss is noticeable for 1 and 2, accompanying amassing of heat, corresponding to the decomposition and oxidation of mal and aromatic chelate ligands. The final product of 1 and 2 is all CuO. The experimental residual percentage weights (23.08% for 1, and 16.66% for 2) at the end of the decomposition of the polymers are consistent with the calculated values of 22.94% for 1 and 16.57% for 2.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic property

The magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 1 and 2 were measured in the temperature range 2-300K. The plots χ M and 1/χ M versus T are shown in    for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The plots of 1/χ M versus T obey the Curie-Weiss law [χ M = C/(T - θ)] with positive Weiss constants of θ =2.18K and θ =5.4K and Curie constant (C) values of 0.376 and 0.40cm3 Kmol-1 for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. In view of the known structure of the complexes, the experimentally determined magnetic behavior was fitted by use of Eq.  . The best fitting parameters obtained are g =2.02, J =0.14cm-1, with an agreement factor R =6.98×10-4 (R =∑[(χ M T)obs -(χ M T)calc]2/∑[(χ M T)obs]2) for 1, and g =2.16, J =0.41cm-1, with an agreement factor R =2.08×10-3 for 2. For both complexes 1 and 2, the fitting results all indicate the magnetic interactions between metal ions and the coordinated ligands are weak ferromagnetic interaction. elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Two novel 1D polymeric chains with the general formula {[Cu(mal)L]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0,4; L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2, 2′-dipyridylamine or 2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine) have been synthesized and characterized. These polymers are based on topologically identical chains where the copper centers chelated by amine ligands are linked by mal bridges. Substitution of 2,2′-dipyridylamine with 2,2′:6′,2″-terpyridine resulted in significant differences in the coordination environment, coordination modes of the mal ligands and chain packing, which indicates the predominant structural role of aromatic–aromatic interactions and the steric effects of these ligands. An appropriate combination of dicarboxylate and aromatic chelate ligands may lead to the formation of zipperlike double-stranded chain or 3D supramolecular network with 1D open channels which are self-organized uniquely by supramolecualar recognition and attraction. More significantly, in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the host framework encapsulates unprecedented 1D water chain in the channel. Both polymers were magnetically characterized and interestingly show weak ferromagnetic behavior.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two novel 1D polymeric chains with the general formula {[Cu(mal)L]⋅ x(H2O)} n  (x =0,4; L=2, 2'-dipyridylamine or 2,2':6',2"-terpyridine) have been synthesized and characterized. These polymers are based on topologically identical chains where the copper centers chelated by amine ligands are linked by mal bridges. Substitution of 2,2'-dipyridylamine with 2,2':6',2"-terpyridine resulted in significant differences in the coordination environment, coordination modes of the mal ligands and chain packing, which indicates the predominant structural role of aromatic-aromatic interactions and the steric effects of these ligands. An appropriate combination of dicarboxylate and aromatic chelate ligands may lead to the formation of zipperlike double-stranded chain or 3D supramolecular network with 1D open channels which are self-organized uniquely by supramolecualar recognition and attraction. More significantly, in 2, the host framework encapsulates unprecedented 1D water chain in the channel. Both polymers were magnetically characterized and interestingly show weak ferromagnetic behavior.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of the complexes

[Cu(mal)(Hdpa)] n  (1)

A suspension of maleate Cu(II) salt (17.8mg, 1mmol) and Hdpa (19.2mg, 1mmol) in methanol solution (10mL) were stirred at room temperature until all the starting materials had dissolved and were replaced with a green powdery precipitate. The mixture was filtered, and a green, clear solution was obtained; dark green crystals of 1 were formed upon standing of the filtrate at room temperature 2 days (9.8mg 28.2%). Anal. Calc. for C14H11CuN3O4 (348.80): C, 48.17; H, 3.15; N, 12.04. Found: C, 48.32; H, 3.01; N, 12.20%.

{[Cu(mal)(tpy)]⋅4H2O}n (2)

Complex 2 was prepared similar to 1. A suspension of maleate Cu(II) salt (17.8mg, 1mmol) and tpy (23.8mg, 1mmol) in methanol solution (15mL) were stirred at room temperature until all the starting materials had dissolved and formed a dark green, clear solution that was immediately filtered; dark green crystals of 2 were formed upon standing of the filtrate at room temperature 3 days (35.3mg 73.1%). Anal. Calc. for C19H21CuN3O8 (482.93): C, 47.21; H, 4.35; N, 8.70. Found: C, 47.32; H, 4.20; N, 8.66%.

<ce:section-title>Thermal analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">To study the thermal stability of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, thermogravimetric analyses and differential scanning calorimetry (TGA and DSC) were performed. The TGA results of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> show that no obvious decomposition was observed until about 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and prove no water molecules in polymers. But the TG curves of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show the first stage of weight loss from 80 to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is mainly due to the release of four water molecules per formula unit. The observed weight loss (14.85% <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) is close to the calculated one (14.91% <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), indicating that the weight loss of water molecules is consistent with the compounds described. Between 200 and 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C the weight loss is noticeable for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, accompanying amassing of heat, corresponding to the decomposition and oxidation of mal and aromatic chelate ligands. The final product of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is all CuO. The experimental residual percentage weights (23.08% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and 16.66% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) at the end of the decomposition of the polymers are consistent with the calculated values of 22.94% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 16.57% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Magnetic property</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The magnetic susceptibilities of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were measured in the temperature range 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal analyses

To study the thermal stability of complexes 1 and 2, thermogravimetric analyses and differential scanning calorimetry (TGA and DSC) were performed. The TGA results of 1 show that no obvious decomposition was observed until about 200°C and prove no water molecules in polymers. But the TG curves of 2 show the first stage of weight loss from 80 to 120°C is mainly due to the release of four water molecules per formula unit. The observed weight loss (14.85% 2) is close to the calculated one (14.91% 2), indicating that the weight loss of water molecules is consistent with the compounds described. Between 200 and 450°C the weight loss is noticeable for 1 and 2, accompanying amassing of heat, corresponding to the decomposition and oxidation of mal and aromatic chelate ligands. The final product of 1 and 2 is all CuO. The experimental residual percentage weights (23.08% for 1, and 16.66% for 2) at the end of the decomposition of the polymers are consistent with the calculated values of 22.94% for 1 and 16.57% for 2.

Magnetic property

The magnetic susceptibilities of complexes 1 and 2 were measured in the temperature range 2-300K. The plots χ M and 1/χ M versus T are shown in    for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The plots of 1/χ M versus T obey the Curie-Weiss law [χ M = C/(T - θ)] with positive Weiss constants of θ =2.18K and θ =5.4K and Curie constant (C) values of 0.376 and 0.40cm3 Kmol-1 for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. In view of the known structure of the complexes, the experimentally determined magnetic behavior was fitted by use of Eq.  . The best fitting parameters obtained are g =2.02, J =0.14cm-1, with an agreement factor R =6.98×10-4 (R =∑[(χ M T)obs -(χ M T)calc]2/∑[(χ M T)obs]2) for 1, and g =2.16, J =0.41cm-1, with an agreement factor R =2.08×10-3 for 2. For both complexes 1 and 2, the fitting results all indicate the magnetic interactions between metal ions and the coordinated ligands are weak ferromagnetic interaction.
